title: 12-Bar Blues in C

musicalLanguage.description: The 12-bar blues is not a song — it's a language. This chord progression (I-I-I-I, IV-IV-I-I, V-IV-I-V) is the foundation of blues, rock and roll, R&B, boogie-woogie, and jazz blues. In C: C7, F7, G7. Three chords, twelve bars, infinite expression. Every blues musician alive knows this form by heart.
musicalLanguage.structure: Three 4-bar phrases: (1) Statement — I chord establishes the key, (2) Response — IV chord lifts, returns to I, (3) Resolution — V chord creates tension, IV answers, I resolves, V turnaround. This is call-and-response in its purest harmonic form.
keyMoments: Measures 1-4: The I chord (C7) — four bars to tell your story. The melody uses the blues scale: C, Eb, F, F#, G, Bb.
Measure 5: The IV chord (F7) arrives — the harmony lifts. Same melody, different ground underneath.
Measure 7: Back to I (C7) — the return feels like coming home.
Measure 9: The V chord (G7) — peak tension. This is the emotional climax of the 12-bar form.
Measure 12: The turnaround (V chord) — sets up the repeat. In blues, the form never ends. It cycles.
teachingGoals: The I-IV-V chord relationship — the three most important chords in Western music
Blues scale: C Eb F F# G Bb C — the b3, b5 (blue note), and b7 give blues its soul
Left hand shuffle pattern: root-5th alternation with a swing feel
The concept of the turnaround — how the last bar sets up the next chorus
Dominant 7th chords: every chord in blues is a 7th chord (1-3-5-b7)
styleTips: Swing the eighths. Straight eighths in blues sound wrong.
The left hand drives — it's the rhythm section. Keep it steady and grounded.
Bend into notes mentally — the space between Eb and E, between F and F#, is where blues lives
Don't fill every beat. Space and silence are expressive tools.
The V-IV-I resolution (bars 9-11) should feel like exhaling after holding your breath

measures.teachingNote: C7 — the tonic. The right hand opens with the blues signature: C to Eb (minor 3rd) to E (major 3rd). That Eb-E crunch IS the blues. Left hand plays the shuffle pattern: root (C3) to fifth (G3), steady as a heartbeat.
Still C7. The melody climbs to C5 and falls back — a small arc. Every note is from the C blues scale. The left hand shuffle continues unchanged.
C7 continues. The melody descends from C5 all the way to C4 — one full octave down. This downward pull is classic blues phrasing: rise up, then tumble down.
Last bar of the I chord. Eb to E (the blue note crush) resolves to G, held for two beats. This sets up the move to the IV chord. The left hand is still on C — about to shift.

F7 — the IV chord. The same blues move transposed up: F to Ab (minor 3rd) to A (major 3rd). That Ab-A crunch is the same gesture as Eb-E over C. Left hand shifts to F3-C4 shuffle. The harmony has lifted — same language, new key center.
F7 continues. The melody descends through C5, Bb4, Ab4 to F4. All F blues scale tones. The IV chord section answers the opening statement.
Back to C7 — the return to the I chord feels like coming home. The melody touches G4, Bb4, C5 — all C7 chord tones — then drops to E4, setting up the next phrase.
C7 — the Eb-E crush again, up to G and Bb, then a rest. That silence before the V chord is dramatic. Let it hang.

G7 — the V chord. Peak tension. B4 (major 3rd of G) and F5 (b7th) form the tritone — the most unstable interval in music. It NEEDS to resolve. Left hand: G3-D4 shuffle. This is the climax of the 12-bar form.
F7 — the IV chord answers the V. The melody descends C5 to Eb4. The tension from bar 9 begins to release. Left hand: F3-C4 shuffle.
C7 — back to the I chord. Resolution. The melody climbs from C4 to C5 — an ascending arpeggio through the blues scale. After the V-IV tension, this feels like breathing again.

The turnaround — G7 (V chord). The melody descends chromatically: G4, F4, Eb4, D4 — pulling back to C for the next chorus. In blues, this bar is a launchpad. The form doesn't end here — it loops. That's the point. Blues is a cycle.

source: Arrangement: AI Jam Session. Traditional 12-bar blues form.
